column1: Will U.S. President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin hold a bilateral meeting in 2021?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'US Policy']
Putin is en route to Geneva
I'm proud of my early analysis months ago. The saying goes you can't have luck with a man who is already made (someone who already made up their mind).
It would be pretty surprising to me if this was called off on the morning it was supposed to happen.

Mark Galeotti has already pointed out that this is a bit dangerous as relations are already fraught and what is actually going on here is an attempt to deescalate – exactly the opposite of a clash. There have already been a raft of op-eds calling on Biden to “hold Putin to account” and “lay down the law” but the reality is this meeting is a result of the fact that Russia has already grown too big and strong to push about any more – which has been Putin’s plan for over a decade and the Geneva meeting is the culmination of that (successful) effort.

Where was this base rate analysis when the question first came out? ;) Biden's Summit With Putin Follows A Harrowing History Of U.S. Meetings With Russia https://www.npr.org/2021/06/12/1004786106/bidens-summit-with-putin-follows-a-harrowing-history-of-u-s-meetings-with-russia
The Geneva summit is on Wednesday
I'd go 99.7 if I could.
Meeting the crowd on this one, the event is scheduled.

cutting in half because the President Eject has been compromising negotiations by threatening to run for the House - get elected Speaker _ and then Impeach which ever People are in office by then. As usual - its all Trumps fault. Harrumph.

They both want this badly, albeit for different reasons. It will happen if they both stay healthy long enough.

Meeting in Geneva June 15
Up 2%. Short time window until announced meeting. No real downsides to it.

My huge forecasting error in an area in which I've got a bit of experience continues to vex. I feel like the economist who, when confronted with contradictory data from the real world, continues to argue, "I'm wrong in practice, of course, but I want to explain why I'm still right in theory!" I see the importance of talking, even--or especially--to competitors and adversaries, but I still am trying to puzzle out why the president would decide to do that at such a high level, rather than at the Secretary of State level or lower. This gives Putin a major victory in return for Russia's malign behavior.
Bloomberg reports Putin-Biden meeting to take place June 15-16.
Breaking news that a US-Russia summit has been scheduled for mid-June in Geneva. Obviously not guaranteed but definitely bringing this up a fair bit.

Kremlin coy on Putin-Biden summit after 'positive' diplomatic talks - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-says-russia-us-talks-positive-signal-putin-biden-summit-2021-05-20/ Thu, 20 May 2021 11:53:00 GMT

https://www.reuters.com/world/kremlin-says-russia-us-talks-positive-signal-putin-biden-summit-2021-05-20/ The signals continue to suggest that this is a go, barring something weird. Something weird is of course never completely barred, but it sounds increasingly like both teams want this.
Challenges with Ukraine are making this more likely. Also, Biden needs communication with Russia to counter China.
Looks like the fix is in U.S. waives sanctions on Nord Stream 2 as Biden seeks to mend Europe ties

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Russia’s Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov are due to hold talks on Wednesday night ahead of a possible presidential summit in June in an attempt to improve the dire relations between the former Cold War foes. https://www.reuters.com/world/us-russia-hold-arctic-talks-push-summit-2021-05-19/ Russian officials on Wednesday said Moscow's fraught ties with Washington could benefit from the waiving of U.S. sanctions on the company in charge of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, after a report said the Biden administration was set to lift them. https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/nord-stream-2-sanctions-waivers-could-help-normalise-russia-us-ties-moscow-says-2021-05-19/

Switzerland is most likely venue for Putin-Biden summit - Russia's Kommersant - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/switzerland-is-most-likely-venue-putin-biden-summit-russias-kommersant-2021-05-17/ Mon, 17 May 2021 19:11:00 GMT

Politico and Reuters both reporting that negotiations are ongoing to have a face-to-face meeting. It seems that the main issue is "where" to a much greater extent than "if." There's always a chance that this falls through, of course, but both sides seem to be trying.

Kinda tight in June given the Group of Seven meeting (which does not include Russia) but the question is open for another 6 months or so. In line with independently consistent reports. I am factoring in the high confidence of some of the forecasters here and also suppressing my bias toward inflating low-probability events like a political escalation elsewhere leading to a degradation of U.S.–Russia relations. Given the time window and no major doubts about this question (although major is subjective here), it feels like a 90% bet to me, but I think I am underconfident around 90%.
Seems the incentives are there on both sides.

Comments: 'In the midst of chaos, there is also opportunity' Sun-Tzu, The Art of War. Affirming forecast. CNN, 05/12/21, 'Blinken to meet Russian Foreign Minister next week': https://www.cnn.com/2021/05/12/politics/antony-blinken-russian-foreign-minister/index.html

Biden is not going to meet with Putin before he meets with some other smaller and less important leaders. As of now it seems that Biden is set to send a message to Putin that he is not who he thinks he is.

Strange to say, but I believe recent "Russian" actions against US infrastructure (and more importantly Biden's measured / muted response [1]) and declarations of withdrawal from some longer standing cooperation agreements [2] are all indications that talks are on the cards and that Putin is manoeuvring "in the lobby" of an up coming bi-lateral to come to the table with an upper hand ("you need me more than I need you" type thing).

U.S. President Biden says he is confident he can meet Russia's Putin soon - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-says-hes-confident-he-will-be-able-meet-putin-soon-2021-05-07/ Fri, 07 May 2021 23:50:00 GMT

https://www.reuters.com/world/us/kremlin-says-date-location-putin-biden-summit-not-yet-decided-2021-04-26/ Coming up rather a lot, and likely to go higher. Vlad the Shirtless is fooling fewer and fewer Russians every day. He badly needs to do something that looks responsible and statesmanlike instead of thuggish; a calm meeting featuring a civil but frank exchange of views would do the trick. For Biden to look good, he only needs to avoid kissing Putin on all four cheeks as the President-Eject was wont to do. They don't need to resolve anything or promise anything, just smile for the cameras and then go solemn as each one declares that they had a meaningful dialogue and are hoping to work together on several issues in future.

A meeting proposed by the Biden admin seems to be well received by the Kremlin. Still some uncertainty if Putin decides to take aggressive action on his Western border or if more U.S. sanctions are imposed, which is a possibility due to the Navalny protests or cyber attacks.

As reported by @dada and @aaseawaf15, there are talks of having summit in June, with even particular dates discussed, At the same time, it is NOT a foregone decision. No working groups were established yet, not to mention potential agenda. There are voices nudging Putin to reject the summit.

Comments: Soft timeframe 'leaked'. Incremental adjustment up. Reuters, 04/25/21, 'Putin and Biden may meet in June -RIA cites Kremlin aide': https://www.reuters.com/world/putin-biden-may-meet-june-ria-cites-kremlin-aide-2021-04-25/

Uncertainty is decreasing - Navalny ended up his hunger strike, Russian troops are pulling out from the Ukrainian border, US Navy is not entering the Black Sea - the last two are clear indications of good will and willingness to diminish tensions. Contacts between the Biden's administration and Russian officials are expanding in lieu of the possible summit... It looks like a a fat tail - when improbable event suddenly becomes quite possible. Of course, this one became possible by deliberate actions of Putin - sending troops to the Ukrainian border. And the summit is not expected to solve any problems - the differences in approaches to international affairs are too deeply entrenched. Still, it is a PR chance for both - Putin as a world leader at least on the level of American President. And Biden diminishing tensions and possible WWIII just by phone call and diplomacy...

A Putin-Biden meeting is good for Putin's legitimacy, but is only helpful for Biden if he can get something out of it, which seems unlikely. The earliest I can see such a meeting occurring is shortly before the mid-terms (aka, fall of 2022) where Biden can make some pretense that helps the Democrats chances in the next election. Much stronger possibility that this relationship further deteriorates than a Biden-Putin summit in 2021.

Some very useful analysis on the potential reasoning, responses and outcomes to Russia's recent actions on force projection: the key point here being who holds the cards and who needs to placate whom.
Increased the probability of a meeting due to the news that Biden proposed a meeting.

Took time to read and think on this one. Returning back to the previous premise that, despite the offer from the Biden White house, this is not likley to go ahead with up coming events (and Russia's traditional / trended / expected response):

To add to more uncertainty - one of the potential hosts of the summit, Czechia, (the latter, Finland and Austria announced their readiness to host) got into a spat with Russia, after expelling 18 Russian diplomats and Russia expelling 20 Czechs in response. And Navalny was transferred to another prison camp, which has a hospital on its premises. If he dies, it will be hard for Biden to hold a summit with a "killer". At the same time, I still assess that the summit most probably will happen as interests of both states nudge in that direction.

https://tass.com/world/1279383 https://www.prudentpressagency.com/finland-and-austria-are-preparing-to-host-the-putin-and-biden-summit/ Going down on the lack of immediate acceptance. Overall, very uncertain.

So Biden told Putin about sanctions in that talk. So they (the sanctions) weren't surprise for Putin. BIden even told Putin that he (Biden) does not go too far with sanctions apparently in order to keep channels open for cooperation. The subsequent posturing of Russian politicians after sanctions was... just PR.

Biden called, offered a summit.. Imposed sanctions ... After the Trump era, Biden probably needs to clearly signal the change he is bringing.. Putin's objective remains disruptive.. to be the chessplayer who maximizes his (Russian) influence... the sanctions make it less palatable.. in the end, it could happen, even if the new status quo remains unaltered..

+20 to eat a helping of crow. Very surprised that Biden would offer to meet directly with Putin while Russia masses troops near Ukraine and the U.S. imposes sanctions. I am still not sure that Putin will accept, but he craves being treated and being seen to be treated as an equal of the President of the United States.

Though new sanctions do not quite hurt Russia, they definitely have propaganda value to nudge Putin to reject the offer of the summit. And also the sanctions show that the US still does not want to treat Russia as equal - the main desire of the Russian government.

It's the dance of the seventh-graders: Folks of different, shall we say, temperaments and value systems sitting on opposite sides of a large room, inching toward actual interaction, but first making sure everybody understands they're only doing it because they've been told they're supposed to. The principals are still at the stage of flashing ambiguous signals, so this will take a while yet. (It will end like the seventh-grade dance. too--a quick desultory turn around the dance floor followed by a relieved rush back to the rest of the team at the far wall.

Comments: Pragmatism reigns. Affirming forecast. Vox, 02/11/21, 'How will Biden handle China and Russia? Look at his calls with Xi and Putin': https://www.vox.com/22277212/biden-xi-call-china-russia-putin-foreign-policy Clips from article: 'Wednesday’s conversation underscores one of the earliest themes of Biden’s foreign policy: He won’t back down against major US adversaries, but he won’t just feud with them, either. Biden has so far followed a consistent blueprint for facing America’s great-power competitors: The US will criticize and even punish China and Russia for human rights abuses, cyberattacks, and predatory economic practices, but it will also seek to cooperate with them when interests align. Take Biden’s first call with Russian President Vladimir Putin in January. Biden pressed his counterpart on the poisoning of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny — suspected by many to have been an assassination attempt ordered by the Kremlin — as well as the government’s arrest of hundreds of protesters who demonstrated in support of Navalny. Biden also affirmed America’s support for Ukraine’s sovereignty, which has been under threat since Russia invaded the country in 2014. But those major policy disagreements didn’t stop the US and Russia earlier this month, when the two countries agreed to extend the last remaining nuclear treaty between them for another five years. Though Secretary of State Tony Blinken released a statement praising the move, he also said that “we remain clear eyed about the challenges that Russia poses to the United States and the world.” “Even as we work with Russia to advance U.S. interests, so too will we work to hold Russia to account for adversarial actions as well as its human rights abuses, in close coordination with our allies and partners,” Blinken added. Biden’s isn’t a fully confrontational approach, then, but rather a transactional one. There are many things on which Washington disagrees with Beijing and Moscow — and Biden will let them know about it — but there are also some areas where the adversaries can work together. Biden doesn’t want to shut the door on making progress in those areas. It’s a fine message to send early on, but it’s also a tricky situation to navigate over the long term. Should China further antagonize Taiwan, or Russia launch more cyberattacks against the US, for example, Biden will have less room to pursue cooperation with those countries. The possibility for plunging ties remains. But UT Austin’s Greitens believes calls like the one Biden just had with Xi could help mitigate such problems. “Clarity on the strength and nature of US concerns is important to avoid misunderstanding,” she told me. “It’s best for the US and China to try to clearly delineate where they can cooperate, where it serves both countries’ interests, so that the cooperation is on a sound footing.”

There does not appear to be any love lost between Biden and Putin. The initial phone call between the two leaders was described as ‘ frank and business like’ that can be construed as tense discussions. The good news was an agreement to extend START by February 5th, 2021 but Biden made it clear the concern including the unprecedented mass hacking of U.S. computers that has been widely blamed on Russia, interference in the 2020 presidential election and reports that Moscow offered bounties for the killing of U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan. In addition to raising Navalny's case, Biden flagged the "treatment of peaceful protesters by Russian security forces.’ In 2011 Biden said, ‘Mr Prime Minister, I’m looking into your eyes, I don’t think you have a soul.’ Putin, it has been suggested that Putin remembers personal attacks and will never forget it. Dmitri Trenin, Director of the Carnegie Endowment’s Moscow Centre suggests that the initial phone call promises no reset and that a confrontation has to managed safely. Given Biden’s indifference to forging a close relationship with the Russian President and the time it takes to prepare for a summit meeting, I will suggest the chances of a face-to-face meeting between Putin and Biden are minimal.

"President Joe Biden held his first call Tuesday with his Russian counterpart, according to the White House, confronting President Vladimir Putin over a range of issues from a recent massive cyberattack to the suspected poisoning of the country's leading opposition figure. The call, which occurred midday, amounted to Biden's opening bid at diplomacy with one of his chief adversaries, whom he has met previously but not dealt with as an equal.[...] But he's also made an opening bid for diplomacy on the nuclear treaty, suggesting he is open to fostering a working relationship with Putin. 'I find that we can both operate in the mutual self-interest of our countries, as a new START agreement, and make it clear to Russia that we are very concerned about their behavior, whether it's Navalny, whether it's the Solar Winds or whether it's reports of bounties on the heads of Americans in Afghanistan,' he told reporters on Monday."

Since the end of the cold war, the likelihood of an American President and Russian President meeting within the first year of office is high. According to the State Department, since President H.W. Bush, all US presidents have held a bilateral meeting with a Russian leader (president or prime minister) within their first year of office. Because a side-bar or virtual meeting would not count for this specific question, I am lowering my probability, based on the continued COVID pandemic. Specific to the context of Biden's foreign policy, his administration is looking like it will directly addressing the Russian government on several issues, including interference in US elections, stifling of political opposition, and proxy war in Syria and Afghanistan. There will certainly be a change in tone from this administration from the last, with Biden's State Department likely focusing on containment in the near term. Confronting Putin directly in a one-on-one bilateral meeting would be a bold move, but likely a smart one. https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/01/22/bidens-russia-moves-signal-a-different-kind-of-reset/ https://2001-2009.state.gov/r/pa/ho/pubs/fs/85962.htm

A bilateral meeting of the kind indicated in the terms of reference for this question would generally be the result of a process that leads to a new agreement or some important milestone in the bilateral relationship. In simplest terms, it would be a reward to the other country. After President Biden has just tasked the intelligence community with providing an updated assessment of the Russian government's hostile actions toward U.S. interests over the last four years [1], it strikes me as unlikely that President Biden would want one of his first major meetings during his first year in office to be with Vladimir Putin. In keeping with President Biden's expressed desire to return to normalcy, his first bilateral meetings are likely to be with close allies in Canada, Europe, and Asia. A major goal of Putin is to be seen as a peer super power. This sort of meeting would create that optic. It is hard to see how President Biden would give this sort of benefit with nothing in return while asking our intelligence community to assess the damage to U.S. interests from Russia.

Historically, meetings between US and Russian Presidents were occurring every 4 years in the 1990’s to early 2000’s (usually in the first year of a US presidential term, though that trend broke down after George W. Bush left office), but they became less frequent recently, with the last meeting between President Trump and Putin in 2018. So the macro trend would predict 4 or more years until the next meeting, but a heavier chance of occurrence in the first year of the new presidential term. More specifically, with recent relations between the countries further deteriorating due to the entrance of the Biden administration and accusations of Russian responsibility for the massive solar winds cyber breach, and with a global pandemic miring both counties in domestic health crises, it is less likely either President would be urgently seeking any kind of meeting or summit this year. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Russia–United_States_summits

Background incidence = 6 out of the last 7 presidential terms had a Russian summit in the first year = 85%. Would Biden be more or less likely to meet Putin? Factors making a sumit more likely: Biden's Russian experience during the cold war and immediate offer of NewStart Extension. Factors making a sumit less likely: Covid restrictions (likely to be overcome later in 2021, at least for presidents), other priorities meaning this gets pushed back to after 2021. Reluctance of Putin due to sanctions, bad press over Alexy Navalny arrest etc
Biden is likely to focus on domestic issues and Covid before taking any public foreign policy meetings.

President Biden will not have the time, nor motivation, to have a bilateral meeting with Vladimir Putin. During the election, President Biden called Russia the biggest threat to the United States in the world [1]. Second, The Biden Administration has listed a COVID-19 response, racism, climate change, and the economy as their top priorities [2]. That means that foreign policy is not a top priority for the current administration and relations with Russia are an even lower priority than that.
Biden has too much on his plate domestically. He’ll have bilats on the margins of big meetings (UNGA, G7) and meetings with leaders of other nations first.

The imminent START treaty extension date (Feb 21) is an interesting inducement for a meeting that I’d missed in my original forecast, as is the announcement in the last 24 hours that Russia is, publicly at least, welcoming the incoming US President’s endorsement of it (https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/biden-administration-approach-russia-about-extension-new-start-nuclear-treaty-n1255187).
I agree with @probahilliby

All previous presidents since Clinton have met with the Russian leader in their presidencies, half of the meetings occuring within a year in office. Putin is here to stay, god willing Biden too. The START treaty is an incentive to have a meeting. A chance of any scheduled meeting being cancelled seems unlikely to me. A chance that a meeting is ignored or not planned at all also seems low to me. Virtual meeting? Now there's a substantial NO resolution factor. With the COVID numbers going down or reaching stable rates early in the year and early in Biden's presidency, I see some reason to believe they will meet in person. However, you cannot exclude the possibility of deferring such a meeting to a later date or holding a virtual one. Processing these factors, I would say about 30% is a comfortable probability.

20% is a baseline (historic rate) Covid takes this rate down But I think Biden *will* want to meet Putin, because of the long feud. It's kind of "look, I'm the President now". So all in all, I'd say 40% chance. I'd say 80% if it would not be for Covid. And the moment Biden starts flying to meet leaders of other countries, I'd up my forecast.

Picking up on @Leonardthethird 's periodic assessment of bi-laterals and expanding to include WHEN in the US president's term the meeting took place:
Fat marker outside view: US/Russia bilateral summits have occurred at an average rate of 1 in 5.06 years since 1993. (~20% likelihood per year), with the last occurring in July 2018. [1]
